sections.section: IBM Integration Bus provides a way to integrate with external application through the TCP/IP sockets. Two sets of TCP/IP nodes exist: TCPIPServer nodes and TCPIPClient nodes. Both can access the data streams; however, one set uses server connections and the other set uses client connections. The connection details can be specified on the nodes directly using port and host (only by Client nodes) or using specialized configurable services. This tutorial uses configurable services as a convenient way to manage the TCP/IP connections.

This tutorial includes an application that simulates a TCP/IP Server TCPIPServer that is enabled to send data over the sockets. The port for the server is defined by a TCPServer configurable service. The main flow in the application is driven by an XML message arriving on the HTTP input node. Once the flow with TCP/IP Server node is deployed the server is started automatically and server connection is opened.

Another application TCPClient contains a flow that is driven by the TCPIP Client input node. By default this node does not open a client connection automatically when deployed. This is why we need to use a TCPIPClient configurable service to set the connection details for the node. This configurable service defines the server host, port, minimum number of connections automatically opened when the flow is deployed. In this case once the flow is deployed the client connection is opened and the node is ready for the arrival of data in the stream.

It is important to ensure that the TCPIP Client Input node understands how detect the record contents from the stream. This can be configured on the 'Records and Elements' node configuration tab. In this tutorial the record detection is set as 'Parsed Record Sequence' to use XML closing tags as a detection mechanism.

The TCPClient flow receives the message from the stream and then maps the incoming message to a different message format to write the output to the file using File Output node. In both applications Trace nodes are used to record the progress of the flows.
Shared library DataLibrary contains the data model that defines the message formats used by the applications.

overview.name: Create
overview.heading: Import source code
overview._createComment: A description of what will happen when the user clicks Import.

sections.section: Click Import to see appllications TCPIPServer, TCPIPClient and DataLibrary in your workspace.

Application TCPIPServer contains a message flow that receives the initial XML message through HTTP Input node. Then the message to passed to the Trace node to write the message body into a trace file. After recording the trace the message is sent over the TCP/IP stream by TCPIP Server Output node using the port 7778 specified by the configurable service TCPIPTutorialServerCF.

Application TCPIPClient contains a message flow which contains the TCPIP Client Input node that receives the data from the host and port defined by the configurable service TCPIPTutorialClientCF. Then the Trace node writes the message to the trace file and passes it to the mapping node that transforms the message to a diferent format that is written to the output file through the File Output node.

Shared library DataLibrary contains a message models for the input and output message formats SaleReport.xsd, SaleMessage.xsd as well as test message that will be used to initiate the tutorial flow TestSaleMessage.xml. It also contains a batch file that contains commands that need to be executed in the IBM Integration Console to create both required configurable services configure_tcpip.bat.

overview.name: Prepare
overview.heading: Exploring the flows and creating configurable services
overview._prepareComment: A description of what just happened when the user clicked Import, and what will happen when the user clicks Deploy.

sections.section: Open the message flow TCPIPProvider.msgflow in the application TCPIPServer by double-clicking the flow.
The flow sticky notes attached to the nodes provide details of node configuration. You can explore the node configuration in the <bold>Properties</bold> view by selecting nodes on the editor canvas.
Note that the Connection details property of TCPIP Server Output Node points to a configurable service TCPIPTutorialServerCF.
This flow is configured to return as soon as the message is sent over TCP IP socket to teh client.

If you open the message flow TCPIPReceiver.msgflow in the application TCPIPClient by double-clicking the flow you can also view more information about particular node configuration using the sticky notes.

Again note that the Connection details property of TCPIP Client Input Node points to a configurable service TCPIPTutorialClientCF. Also see how the Records and Elements tab allows you to configure the record detection.

Note that to successfully deploy your application to the target integration server you need to create two required configurable services. To create the configurable service on the target integration node TESTNODE_ used by the flow excercizer run the provided configure_tcpip.bat file in the IBM Integration Console (Windows). On linux you can just run the mqsicreateconfigurableservice commands from the bat file individually in the IIB command prompt.

Tips:You may need to adjust the ports in the configurable services commands for your system if the 7778 can not be used. By default the FileOutput node on the TCPIPServerReceiver flow specifies the target file as C:\temp\TCPClientTutorialOutput.txt. You can change it if this path on the File Output node Basic configuration tab.
Next, you will deploy and run the tutorial to see how the data travels from the TCPIPServer to the TCPIPClient and then to the file on the file system. Click Run to see those steps.

sections.section: Deploy and run the tutorial flows:

details.details: Open the flow TCPIPProvider.msgflow from the application TCPIPServerProviderby double clicking on it. Click the Flow Exerciser icon to start recording the message path through the flow.
Click the Send Message icon to select a message to send to the flow.

Add a new input message to the tree on the left and check the Import from file option. Then select the file from the workspace /DataLibrary/TestSaleMessage.xml. Then click Send button to invoke the flow.
After the request message is processed, the message path is automatically highlighted on the message flow.

sections.section: Verify the flow execution:

details.details: Click on any connection to see the data that passed through that connection.
You can also open a trace file specified by the Trace nodes (C:\temp\TCPIP_TRACE.txt) in both flows to see the messages from every trace node.
In the same output directory you should see the output file created by the file output node (C:\temp\TCPClientTutorialOutput.txt). The file should contain the transformed message SalesReport.
To stop recording the message path through the flow, click the Return flow to edit mode icon .

You can click Clean up action to remove the tutorial source code from the workspace. You need to manually go to the target integration servers and delete the deployed applictaions using Delete context menu.
